elements.content: Catenation based on homochiral metal–organic nanocages or nanotubes is realized in this work for the first time. A flexible enantiopure ligand is employed to assemble metal ions, with the structure-directing effect of an auxiliary ligand, a triangular-prism-like nanocage, and a nanotube successfully built. Further 0D → 3D catenation is achieved by interlocking the nanocages, and 1D → 3D catenation based on nanotubes is also presented. This work reveals extraordinary catenating architectures from molecular cages and tubes.
elements.clean_text: Catenation based on homochiral metal-organic nanocages or nanotubes is realized in this work for the first time. A flexible enantiopure ligand is employed to assemble metal ions, with the structure-directing effect of an auxiliary ligand, a triangular-prism-like nanocage, and a nanotube successfully built. Further 0D → 3D catenation is achieved by interlocking the nanocages, and 1D → 3D catenation based on nanotubes is also presented. This work reveals extraordinary catenating architectures from molecular cages and tubes.

elements.content: Presented here is the catenated assembly of homochiral metal−organic nanocages or nanotubes based on enantiopure ligands. 0D → 3D catenation is achieved by interlocking the nanocages, and 1D → 3D catenation of nanotubes is also realized.
elements.clean_text: Presented here is the catenated assembly of homochiral metal-organic nanocages or nanotubes based on enantiopure ligands. 0D → 3D catenation is achieved by interlocking the nanocages, and 1D → 3D catenation of nanotubes is also realized.

elements.content: Interpenetrated and interlocked molecules such as catenanes and rotaxanes have received much attention not only for their potential applications in information processing and storage and molecular electronics but also for their interesting topological structures. An efficient strategy for the construction of catenanes and rotaxanes is to use discrete coordination cages as components to construct interlocked structures in situ. In principle, each vertex of metallacages is a potential linking point for the formation of a catenane. By the use of coordination-driven self-assembly, several metallacages with various sizes and shapes, such as tetrahedra, octahedra, and cubes, have been produced. Recently, several examples of discrete cages have also been obtained from enantiopure organic ligands, However, catenated assembly of homochiral metal–organic nanocages or nanotubes based on enantiopure ligands has never been realized to date.
elements.clean_text: Interpenetrated and interlocked molecules such as catenanes and rotaxanes have received much attention not only for their potential applications in information processing and storage and molecular electronics but also for their interesting topological structures. An efficient strategy for the construction of catenanes and rotaxanes is to use discrete coordination cages as components to construct interlocked structures in situ. In principle, each vertex of metallacages is a potential linking point for the formation of a catenane. By the use of coordination-driven self-assembly, several metallacages with various sizes and shapes, such as tetrahedra, octahedra, and cubes, have been produced. Recently, several examples of discrete cages have also been obtained from enantiopure organic ligands, However, catenated assembly of homochiral metal-organic nanocages or nanotubes based on enantiopure ligands has never been realized to date.

elements.content: Herein we describe a homochiral compound, {Zn3[(R)-TMTA]2[(1R,2R)-cyclohexanediamine]3} n (1; TMTA = 1,3,5-trimethyl-1,3,5-triazine), composed of catenated triangular-prism-like cages based on a presynthesized enantiopure (R)-H3TMTA ligand (), in which 0D → 3D catenation is achieved by interlocking the cages. By using different organic amines as the structure-directing agent, another homochiral compound, {Zn3[(R)-TMTA]2(cyclohexylamine)6} n (2), with 1D → 3D catenation based on nanotubes is also presented.
elements.clean_text: Herein we describe a homochiral compound, {Zn3[(R)-TMTA]2[(1R,2R)-cyclohexanediamine]3} n  (1; TMTA = 1,3,5-trimethyl-1,3,5-triazine), composed of catenated triangular-prism-like cages based on a presynthesized enantiopure (R)-H3TMTA ligand (), in which 0D → 3D catenation is achieved by interlocking the cages. By using different organic amines as the structure-directing agent, another homochiral compound, {Zn3[(R)-TMTA]2(cyclohexylamine)6} n  (2), with 1D → 3D catenation based on nanotubes is also presented.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Catenated Assembly of Homochiral Metal–Organic
Nanocages or
Nanotubes Based on an Enantiopure Ligand</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" position="float" xlink:href="ic-2016-00574s_0006.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
elements.clean_text: 1  Catenated Assembly of Homochiral Metal-Organic Nanocages or Nanotubes Based on an Enantiopure Ligand

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray structural determination reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the trigonal chiral space group P321. The independent unit of 1 is composed of three Zn2+ cations, three (1R,2R)-cyclohexanediamine auxiliary ligands, and two (R)-TMTA3– ligands (Figure S1). The tetrahedral coordinated Zn atom acts as the linker to connect two (R)-TMTA3– ligands through Zn–O bonds, and its two left coordination sites are occupied by two N atoms from one cyclohexanediamine in chelating mode. Each (R)-TMTA3– ligand coordinates to three Zn atoms by its three carboxyl groups.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray structural determination reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the trigonal chiral space group P321. The independent unit of 1 is composed of three Zn2+ cations, three (1R,2R)-cyclohexanediamine auxiliary ligands, and two (R)-TMTA3- ligands (Figure S1). The tetrahedral coordinated Zn atom acts as the linker to connect two (R)-TMTA3- ligands through Zn-O bonds, and its two left coordination sites are occupied by two N atoms from one cyclohexanediamine in chelating mode. Each (R)-TMTA3- ligand coordinates to three Zn atoms by its three carboxyl groups.

elements.content: The prominent structural feature of 1 is the presence of a triangular-prism-like homochiral nanocage. Three Zn2+ cations connect three (R)-TMTA3– ligands, which only consider two of the three arms to give a neutral trigonal fragment. Considering the third arm of the (R)-TMTA3– ligand, the trigonal fragment behaves as a tridentate ligand, leading to the formation of a {Zn3[(R)-TMTA]3}3– anionic unit, and three free arms are arranged on the same side of the plane. Subsequently, two {Zn3[(R)-TMTA]3}3– units in opposite directions are linked by another three Zn2+ cations to produce a perfectly enclosed {Zn9[(R)-TMTA]6} nanocage (a). This nanocage can be simplified as the triangular prism, in which six (R)-TMTA3– ligands define the six vertices as the 3-connected nodes and nine metal ions positioned at nine edges as the linker to connect the nodes (b). Note that a few prism-like coordination molecular nanocages have been reported previously; their common feature is that the flexible ligands or organic/inorganic macrocyclic units are positioned on the faces or edges and the metal atoms occupy the vertices of the metallacages. To the best of our knowledge, the nanocage reported in this work is the first example in which the metal and ligands play opposite roles.
elements.clean_text: The prominent structural feature of 1 is the presence of a triangular-prism-like homochiral nanocage. Three Zn2+ cations connect three (R)-TMTA3- ligands, which only consider two of the three arms to give a neutral trigonal fragment. Considering the third arm of the (R)-TMTA3- ligand, the trigonal fragment behaves as a tridentate ligand, leading to the formation of a {Zn3[(R)-TMTA]3}3- anionic unit, and three free arms are arranged on the same side of the plane. Subsequently, two {Zn3[(R)-TMTA]3}3- units in opposite directions are linked by another three Zn2+ cations to produce a perfectly enclosed {Zn9[(R)-TMTA]6} nanocage (a). This nanocage can be simplified as the triangular prism, in which six (R)-TMTA3- ligands define the six vertices as the 3-connected nodes and nine metal ions positioned at nine edges as the linker to connect the nodes (b). Note that a few prism-like coordination molecular nanocages have been reported previously; their common feature is that the flexible ligands or organic/inorganic macrocyclic units are positioned on the faces or edges and the metal atoms occupy the vertices of the metallacages. To the best of our knowledge, the nanocage reported in this work is the first example in which the metal and ligands play opposite roles.

elements.content: (a) Assembly of a {Zn9[(R)-TMTA]6} nanocage. (b) Simplified triangular-prism topology of the nanocage and catenated nanocages. (c) 6-connected acs topology representing the polycatenated framework in 1 by considering the nanocage as the 6-connected node.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Assembly of a {Zn9[(R)-TMTA]6} nanocage. (b) Simplified triangular-prism topology of the nanocage and catenated nanocages. (c) 6-connected acs topology representing the polycatenated framework in 1 by considering the nanocage as the 6-connected node.

elements.content: Another outstanding structural feature of 1 is its unique polycatenation between discrete {Zn9[(R)-TMTA]6} nanocages. As illustrated in b, each triangular-prism-like nanocage is catenated by six nanocages through all of its six vertices. It is worth noting that the overall architecture is produced with mechanical linkages rather than by common coordination bonding interactions. The propagation of the sextuple polycatenation of each discrete triangular-prism-like nanocage generates an unprecedented 3D extended polycatenated polyhedral architecture. Continuous catenation between the nanocages in three different directions forms a beautiful 3D polycatenated structure of 1. From a topological viewpoint, if each homochiral {Zn9[(R)-TMTA]6} nanocage is considered to be a 6-connected node, with the catenation as a linkage between nodes, the structure of 1 can be described as the acs topological network (c). To the best of our knowledge, compound 1 represents the first example of 0D → 3D catenation based on homochiral metal–organic nanocages.
elements.clean_text: Another outstanding structural feature of 1 is its unique polycatenation between discrete {Zn9[(R)-TMTA]6} nanocages. As illustrated in b, each triangular-prism-like nanocage is catenated by six nanocages through all of its six vertices. It is worth noting that the overall architecture is produced with mechanical linkages rather than by common coordination bonding interactions. The propagation of the sextuple polycatenation of each discrete triangular-prism-like nanocage generates an unprecedented 3D extended polycatenated polyhedral architecture. Continuous catenation between the nanocages in three different directions forms a beautiful 3D polycatenated structure of 1. From a topological viewpoint, if each homochiral {Zn9[(R)-TMTA]6} nanocage is considered to be a 6-connected node, with the catenation as a linkage between nodes, the structure of 1 can be described as the acs topological network (c). To the best of our knowledge, compound 1 represents the first example of 0D → 3D catenation based on homochiral metal-organic nanocages.

elements.content: When cyclohexylamine was employed to replace (1R,2R)-cyclohexanediamine, compound 2 was obtained under similar reaction conditions. In the structure of 2, the Zn atom and (R)-TMTA3– ligand present similar coordination modes observed in 1. A slight difference is that two cyclohexylamine ligands replace one (1R,2R)-cyclohexanediamine ligand. In comparison, compound 2 shows low symmetry and crystallizes in the orthorhombic chiral I212121 space group. Four (R)-TMTA3– ligands were linked by four Zn2+cations to form a four-membered ring with the formation of {Zn4[(R)-TMTA]4}4–. Two adjacent {Zn4[(R)-TMTA]4}4– units were further connected by another four Zn2+ cations in the opposite direction to form the {Zn12[(R)-TMTA]8} fragment (a,b). Such fragments finally combined with each other in a head-to-tail mode to form a double-zigzag chain (DZC) along the b axis. This DZC chain can also be considered as a 1D nanotube viewed along the b axis. Then each nanotube is catenated by four others to generate an unprecedented 3D framework (c).
elements.clean_text: When cyclohexylamine was employed to replace (1R,2R)-cyclohexanediamine, compound 2 was obtained under similar reaction conditions. In the structure of 2, the Zn atom and (R)-TMTA3- ligand present similar coordination modes observed in 1. A slight difference is that two cyclohexylamine ligands replace one (1R,2R)-cyclohexanediamine ligand. In comparison, compound 2 shows low symmetry and crystallizes in the orthorhombic chiral I212121 space group. Four (R)-TMTA3- ligands were linked by four Zn2+cations to form a four-membered ring with the formation of {Zn4[(R)-TMTA]4}4-. Two adjacent {Zn4[(R)-TMTA]4}4- units were further connected by another four Zn2+ cations in the opposite direction to form the {Zn12[(R)-TMTA]8} fragment (a,b). Such fragments finally combined with each other in a head-to-tail mode to form a double-zigzag chain (DZC) along the b axis. This DZC chain can also be considered as a 1D nanotube viewed along the b axis. Then each nanotube is catenated by four others to generate an unprecedented 3D framework (c).

elements.content: (a) Representation of the formation of a nanotube in 2. (b) View of the 1D nanotube in 2. (c) Catenated nanotubes in 2. (d) Simplified topology representing the polycatenated framework in 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Representation of the formation of a nanotube in 2. (b) View of the 1D nanotube in 2. (c) Catenated nanotubes in 2. (d) Simplified topology representing the polycatenated framework in 2.

elements.content: It is worth mentioning the generation of catenation in compounds 1 and 2. By checking the structure carefully, we considered that the organic amine plays a crucial role in such a self-assembly process. In 1, each (1R,2R)-cyclohexanediamine provides two N atoms to coordinate one Zn atom, which generates enough space to ensure catenation of the nanocage. The π–π interactions and strong intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions in 1 make the final framework more stable. However, each Zn atom coordinated by two cyclohexylamine ligands in 2 genarates larger steric hindrance than one (1R,2R)-cyclohexanediamine ligand in 1, which may be proven by observation of the lower symmetry, larger bond angle of N–Zn–N, and larger centroid distances of the ligands in 2. So, the {Zn4[(R)-TMTA]4}4– anionic units mentioned before were connected by four Zn2+ cations in opposite directions to form the {Zn12[(R)-TMTA]8} fragment rather than the formation of a nanocage to reduce such steric hindrance and stabilize the final framework (Figure S3).
elements.clean_text: It is worth mentioning the generation of catenation in compounds 1 and 2. By checking the structure carefully, we considered that the organic amine plays a crucial role in such a self-assembly process. In 1, each (1R,2R)-cyclohexanediamine provides two N atoms to coordinate one Zn atom, which generates enough space to ensure catenation of the nanocage. The π-π interactions and strong intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions in 1 make the final framework more stable. However, each Zn atom coordinated by two cyclohexylamine ligands in 2 genarates larger steric hindrance than one (1R,2R)-cyclohexanediamine ligand in 1, which may be proven by observation of the lower symmetry, larger bond angle of N-Zn-N, and larger centroid distances of the ligands in 2. So, the {Zn4[(R)-TMTA]4}4- anionic units mentioned before were connected by four Zn2+ cations in opposite directions to form the {Zn12[(R)-TMTA]8} fragment rather than the formation of a nanocage to reduce such steric hindrance and stabilize the final framework (Figure S3).

elements.content: (a) Solid-state CD spectra for compounds 1 and 2. (b) Enantioselective recognition of carvone in ethanol solutions with compound 2.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Solid-state CD spectra for compounds 1 and 2. (b) Enantioselective recognition of carvone in ethanol solutions with compound 2.

elements.content: The enantiopure nature of the two compounds was proved by solid-state circular dichroism (CD) measurements in a pressed dry KCl disk (a), which motivated us to explore the ability of chiral recognition. Considering the rich hydrogen-bonding environment of the surface and the carbonyl O atom of carvone as the hydrogen-bond acceptor, we just used the samples without guest exchange to do the experiment of chiral recognition. The ethanol solution of l-carvone and d-carvone with the same concentration of 10–3 mol/L and amount of 2 mL were placed in different cells. Then same amount of compound 1 was added to the two cells. The corresponding CD signals were recorded. The similar experiments were conducted on compound 2. The CD intensity of both solutions with compound 1 hardly changed. As shown in b, when compound 2 was added, the intensity of d-carvone decreased more markedly than that of l-carvone. This may mean that the interactions between compound 2 and d-carvone are stronger than those between 2 and l-carvone.
elements.clean_text: The enantiopure nature of the two compounds was proved by solid-state circular dichroism (CD) measurements in a pressed dry KCl disk (a), which motivated us to explore the ability of chiral recognition. Considering the rich hydrogen-bonding environment of the surface and the carbonyl O atom of carvone as the hydrogen-bond acceptor, we just used the samples without guest exchange to do the experiment of chiral recognition. The ethanol solution of l-carvone and d-carvone with the same concentration of 10-3 mol/L and amount of 2 mL were placed in different cells. Then same amount of compound 1 was added to the two cells. The corresponding CD signals were recorded. The similar experiments were conducted on compound 2. The CD intensity of both solutions with compound 1 hardly changed. As shown in b, when compound 2 was added, the intensity of d-carvone decreased more markedly than that of l-carvone. This may mean that the interactions between compound 2 and d-carvone are stronger than those between 2 and l-carvone.

elements.content: In summary, the catenated assembly of homochiral metal–organic nanocages or nanotubes based on enantiopure ligands was first reported here. The catenating architectures from metal–organic cages and tubes with homochirality open a new approach toward the construction of functional catenanes.
elements.clean_text: In summary, the catenated assembly of homochiral metal-organic nanocages or nanotubes based on enantiopure ligands was first reported here. The catenating architectures from metal-organic cages and tubes with homochirality open a new approach toward the construction of functional catenanes.

metadata.title:
